ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A deeper appreciation for where theater and acting technique REALLY comes from.

An in-depth understanding of the development of Western acting technique and the lives of its most important figures. We also did exercises to familiarize ourselves with the techniques of various practitioners, including Stanislavsky, Meyerhold, and Chekhov.
Deep dive into the history of Russian theater makers of the 20th century.
Understanding of the lineage/history of Stanislavsky and his ideas, improved understanding of those ideas themselves, introduction to other directors/artists like Meyerhold.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class was often tiring because of that dreaded nearly 4-hour slot on Thursdays. Perhaps it could be divided into 2-hour slots of 2 days per week, though I know that'd be much harder for David with his commute from Cambridge.

I might suggest more active floorwork during class time, as staying focused on taking in information and having discussion for most of a four hour class was pretty difficult at times. However I did really appreciate the freedom in discussions to take them wherever was most interesting to usit led to a lot of really interesting and beneficial discussions about the state of American theater today.

Strengths: fabulous material, deeply informed and passionate professor, joy.
Weakness: readings were a bit all of the place and often full of repeated material.
I love the format of the class - presentation followed by discussion followed by floor exercises. I also appreciate that we take meaningful breaks.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: In its current, dense and long-form format, probably not? But I still think the lessons and material covered in the course are invaluable for anyone looking to deepen their knowledge of theater and theater history.

If you're an actor or director, I think this course provides a very necessary background for understanding all of Western theater and acting. It's a lot of history and theory, but David makes it worth it for sure!

If you are interested in the lineage of acting and directing from Russia, it provides a cool overview of that history. It is super niche and probably not for everyone, but if you can find something of interest in the subject material, you can get a lot out of it.
Yes. if you care about art or theater this will open your mind.

Absolutely. Especially as an actor, this course essentially allowed me to understand the context of everything I've been taught over the last 8 years. I feel that this is incredibly valuable, and I am very glad to have had the experience.
